title: Why do so many cursive letters look so different from their print version? I'm particularly thinking about the capital Q. - Quora

response.answer_text: Cursive got it’s start with the monks and abbots in the realm of the Church. The writung was decorative partly as a glorification to God. We lowly humans took things from there. We changed and tinkered. Humans DO that. Sometimes we get it right. More often, a little ill-advised wrongness creeps in over time.

Why do so many cursive letters look so different from their print version? I'm particularly thinking about the capital Q. It is because the letters have become individually stylized by users and have evolved over time.
